title: 110_hr2268
content: The Act may be cited as the "Mother's Day Centennial Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that Anna Jarvis, founder of modern Mother's Day, was born in Webster, West Virginia on May 1, 1864. She dedicated her life to honoring her mother, Anna Reeves Jarvis, leading to the official proclamation of Mother's Day in 1908. Governor William Glasscock issued the first Mother's Day Proclamation in 1910, and in 1914, the Sixty-Third Congress designated the second Sunday in May as Mother's Day. Res. 263 designates the second Sunday in May as Mother's Day and encourages displaying the American flag as a public expression of love for mothers. President Woodrow Wilson issued a proclamation in 1914 for government officials and the public to display the flag on this day. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint $1 coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act shall have a design emblematic of the 100th anniversary of President Wilson's proclamation for Mother's Day. Each coin will include the coin's value, the year "2014", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities starting January 1, 2014, with sales possible before that date. Minting authority will end on December 31, 2014. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. The sale of coins under this Act requires a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges collected will be divided equally between the Susan G. Komen for the Cure and the National Osteoporosis Foundation for research purposes. Both organizations will be audited for the funds received. There is a limitation on the surcharge amount. No surcharge can be added to any coin issued under this Act if it would exceed the annual limit of 2 commemorative coin programs. The Secretary of the Treasury can provide guidance on this limitation. The House of Representatives passed the bill on June 10, 2008. Clerk: LORRAINE C. MILLER.
